10/10 Masterpiece!

This game is amazing, but also the most frustrating game I've ever played (it's my first Souls-like game).
The story mode is interesting, the soundtrack is fenominal, the gameplay is fantastic but very hard to master (I played this game with keyboard + mouse, btw.).

The boss fights are VERY HARD, even the mini-bosses. I've given up many times, but something in my heart tells me I have to finish the game. Not to get all the achievements, but just to finish the game. 

So I tried, tried and tried. I wasted many hours on the same boss. When I reached the final boss (even though I had skipped Owl (Father)), I had a difficult time. 
The final boss reads my inputs and kills me every single time. 

So I did what they call a pro-gamer move: I just installed the "Sekiro The Easy" mod. 
AND BOY OH BOY! THIS MOD IS TOO POWERFUL!!! It only took me two minutes to beat the boss. XD (I wish I had found out about this mod earlier. T_T)
I would still recommend playing the game without mods. I didn't use any mods before the final boss fight and I had one boss fight that took me 3 hours (I'm looking at you, Great Shinobi Owl).
If you just want to experience the story mode, you should use the mod I mentioned. 

(I wish FromSoftware had included an easy or story difficulty mode so blockheads like me could enjoy the game without getting stuck on the same boss for several hours.)

I don't know if I ever want to play a Souls-like game again, since I'm so bad at that genre. It's also very time consuming and I still have a lot of games in my backlog that I need to finish.

Overall:
Anyway, I'm glad this game is available on PC. It would be great if more FromSoftware games were available on GOG. Just for the sake of game preservation.

It's a very one-dimensional game. Did everything up to Genichiro and Lady Butterfly. It's very much a rhythm combat system with nothing else going for it. Every boss encounter is just a parry endurance test and there aren't many ways to approach the boss like in every other Souls/souls-like game. I noped out at Genichiro, three phase boss fights are a no from me dawg. The fight isn't particularly hard, it's just an endurance test and if you mess up a few times you'll use up your resources before the final phase. 

Is it a skill issue? yeah. The problem is the failed attempts aren't fun and there is nothing new to learn with each retry. Once you know their moveset it's just retrying over and over until you hit the timings perfectly. Bosses should feel fun with trial and error and you should get to try new weapons, builds and strategies. You either play the Sekiro way, or the highway.

Im going to make a very bold claim here: The gameplay is objectively bad. 

Its fine if you like it, its fine you "got good", i get the appeal. Its still objectively bad. 

Discplaimer: Im very early on in the game (and Im waiting on a refund), so Im literally just at the 2nd boss - the chained big guy.  From what I can read - but not evaluate in the context of this review - my point about parrying not even being neccessary below would change later on, but I dont know that. 

So let me describe the actual gameplay, vs what you are actually supposed to do with parrying: 

What you are supposed to do: 
Parry attacks from enemies... because otherwise you get fucked. 
Let me make it more clear: Parrying isnt satisfying or per se good (let me explain below), its just that doing something else gets you fucked because of hitboxes. 

How the actual gameplay makes you want to play (again, before and including the chained Ogre Boss):
Normal enemies: Spam attack while isolating them one by one. 
Bosses:  Either dont need to parry (ill explain) or you cant (I dont really see what attacks I can parry with the Ogre boss)

Why am I saying this? And what exactly am I saying:
1) Parrying is stupid
2) Parrying isnt needed, 
3) Except you are kind of forced to...

1) With what I have seen so far, every time in terms of actual gameplay is literally punishing you for parrying:
If I parry an attack from an enemy, my bar fills up, which is bad. Im am literally punished for parrying. So I am literally incentivised to dodge, walk back or to the side or jump up/away. I cannot see (before the chained Ogre boss) any circumstance where parrying would actually help me. 
In fact im confuse entirely about why its even in the game: I can literally just hold the parry button nd dont take any damage, and I never need to release it, because I dont have stamina that stops me from doing so. In fact - from readng discussions on it - doing this, literally recovers your own bar faster. 

Yet somehow parrying is supposed to be the entire "thing" of the game? "You are dancing the with the enemies, not fighting them enymore once you master it" or "Its like music, you have to get the rythm down"
I dont see it. Like at all. 
- Im punished for parrying by having my own bar fill up
- And i literally can just hold the parry button pressed and Im invinceible until I see a red sign and jump away,  which I do anyway, because parrying is literally bad for me in terms of gameplay

Now this applies definitely - and I would argue objectively - to normal enemies, and mostly to bosses. 
Hence point 2) Parrying is quite literally not needed. Not at all for normal enemies and only slightly (so far) for bosses. 

I literally tried this out before the ogre boss. There are the 2 Samurai at the fire. So i killed the first/weak one and then death after death at the ogre boss i just spammed attacks on him without enything else. 100% of the time (like 10 times) he just died and had no counter at all. Even the times when he hit a perfect parry himself (spraky red parry - I assume thats a perfect parry?) literally nothing happened to me and I just kept on spaming attack... because there is literally nothing stopping me. 

Some other enemies sometimes have the red attacks that you need to dodge... except you can more often than not just keep spammming attack to interrupt them from doing it. There is third point here  (4) but Ill explain that later. 
This even works on bosses sometimes and if timed right ( = mostly by accident). 

Above I wrote: 
3) (Parrying isnt needed,) Except you are kind of forced to...

why do I write this: because before the Ogre boss, there is a small boss that y+ou have to slice up 2 times. With that boss, you at least CAN parry - which I cant say about the ogre. And since it was the first real boss i experimented with it a bit. So yeah you can parry... but with his one you still did absoluetly not need to. But you can. 

Except sometimes you are forced to. Its not just an option, but you actually need to. (Im sure if you are a dark Souls speedrunner you ca get over rthis, I wasnt in my 2 hours)
The reason is because the hit boxes often are insane, so dodging is impossible. 

This is also tied to point 4, so lts go over it: 
4) What the hell do you do with those red attacks?
In the tutorial it says that you can - and thats my understanding of it - either jump or dash away from the attack thats not able to be parried. Except both for those "red" attacks but also normal attacks, it often does not work because of the hitbox and a mechanic the bosses have. 
A) Hitboxes: I dont know how many times I for sure dodged an attack or saw the attack go over my head yet I still got hit. Sure Dark Souls (3) isnt perfect here either, but comapred to this its a holy grail of hitbox accuracy
B) From what I can tell, bosses can and do use the same mechanic as a player with focusing on the player with that dot you can focus on the boss too. I came to that conclusion when the ogre boss attacked me by jumping so that he could double kick me in face for a massive hit, and I dodged most of the time, for him to just rotate to me when I dodged to the side. So he literally rotated in the Air to give it to me. 

Now after looking into some discussions I realized that apprently there are swing attack, that you need to JUMP over, but there are also thrust attacks the you need to dodge to the side (like speer pokes). Guess what: They both use the same red symbol and you also cant really tell them apart perfectly. 

This was so bad for me, that at the ogre I tried a few rounds (thats when I also tested the stronger samurai) of just dodging by jumping and just dodging by dashing. There I realized how f'd the htboxes are with me jumping up or to the side for his grab attack (when he jumps, not just grabs in front of him) yet even though I was outside of it, I clipped back into his loving arms. 


5) Last main point for the review: I hate when games queue up attacks as if you cant react to it. Its such a stupid thing. It does not feel good (Not in Dark Souls and not here - havent tried Elden Ring yet) and its so goddamn annoying. I mean try this: Throw a ball, exceptin the middle of throwing it stop. "OMG THATS ANYMOATION CANCELIING AN BLABLABLABLABLA". B*itch shut up. Why the hell do develepers literally have to stop me from reacting to make a game harded. I reacted, let me control my character. 

I hate this and I cant understand why on earth its so har for even From Soft to let go of this relic of who knows when what and where. If I react, let me react MF'er, and its more realisitc. It jsut sad if you need to do this to make it harded. Am i so strong as a player taht you need to articially stop me from dodging/parrying/blocking compared to your bosses?

Just stop with this trope, please. 

----
I can still get why people may like the game, but I objctively think the gameplay is contradictory in its nature and within the gameplay sets the wrong incentives compared for what you actually are supposed to do. From what I read parrying actually becomes neccessary and fun ("Dacne" and "rythm") later on, but I decided to get my money back before I get there, because I have so many other problems than even listed above. 

For highlights of the rest of my complaints:
- Why am I on the ground even if my parry bar isnt filled up?
- Why do I have to watch some stupid animation everytime I die and want to reawaken? ( Is literally any moment in the entire game where you dont want to use it?)
- I never had it once my parry bar was full that I actually got attacked and lost one of my red points. I just spammed jump and jmped away before the enemy as able to do anything....  so again: What the hell is the parry bar there for?
- Why are the bosses so much bigger than me? Even If I parry im s far away from being able to attack, that I need to first run back to them, espcaially once they step back a bit themselves after I parry.

I wanted to dive into this because I had so much fun with Elden Ring. But I did not enjoy this at all. With ER, if you get stuck on a boss you can go explore something else or summon real players to assist you. This does not have that option and I didn't realize how much I appreciated real player summons until I played this. The parrying also felt 'off' to me. I'm sure it's a skill issue but I didn't want to bang my head against the wall just to learn the mechanics.

One of the best games in the genre. The parry mechanic, which is a core part of the game play loop, is hard to pick up but easy to master. The give and take of pressure between the enemy and yourself is satisfying, fluid, and akin to a dance performance. The sound design of each hit, and the combat is so addicting that every enemy you face is an enjoyable experience. The world building is amazing, and the attention to detail is superb. 10/10.

My first Souls-like â and my first FromSoftware experience.
I didnât know it was considered their hardest.
It ended up being the hardest game Iâve ever played â and also the one with the most satisfying combat system Iâve ever experienced.

It almost broke me in the first few hours. (Hello, Chained Ogre!)
I was on the verge of rage quitting â but Iâm glad I didnât.

Sekiro breaks you, yes, but it also remakes you.
Once you absorb all the beating and suffering and still push through,
you start to develop a mindset â even an attitude â toward obstacles.
I think it made me more resilient in the face of repeated failure.
But, I shouldnât hesitate saying that

After all: âHesitation is defeat!â

This game just hits different than anything youâve probably ever played.

Spoiler Warning from here on â youâve been warned.

As an example: the Divine Dragon.
Itâs like the gimmick fight of Sekiroâbasically like Rykard, Lord of Blasphemy from Elden Ring.
The fight overall isnât hard compared to anything youâve really fought before him.
Itâs just the amazing atmosphere that makes the fight memorable for me. Everything about his attacks makes you feel somethingâit feels straight out of an anime.

Or take Isshin, the Sword Saint, the final boss for any ending except the Shura ending.
Yes, the fight is hardâincredibly hardâbut thereâs just something about this fight that feels so right to lose.
You donât fight against some bullshit god-creature like in Elden Ring.
You fight against Genichiroâs grandfather, whose last wish was to fight for Ashina.

And how he fights...
He makes you regret every hit you take.
He makes you scream in rage.
He makes you mad.
But itâs not some stupid Waterfowl Dance move he doesâhe just tests everything youâve been taught so far in the game.
And yesâheâs just the perfect final boss, in my opinion.

It took me around eight hours to see his fourth phase for the first time.
When he just starts catching lightning with his sword and makes you shoot it back at him...
And when you see his poise bar slowly getting fullerâthatâs when you really feel your heart pumping like crazy.

For me, it was the first time ever experiencing something like that:
The music gets quieter, your vision gets fixed on the game,
you forget about everything around you,
and suddenly you donât even hear your stupid friends on Discord anymore.
Itâs just you and the game.

And then, after eleven painful hours, youâre finally able to finish him.
I almost cried out of pure joyâof finally being able to finish my playthrough.
Isshin even motivates you to finally end it.

Just such a unique experience.
10/10 â would recommend for anyone searching for a hard-as-f*ck game.

Sekiro might have the most engaging combat in any From Software title.
I genuinely think it is fantastic from a gameplay perspective and if that's all you care about?
Then ignore the rest of this review and buy it.

But it is a very substandard PC port.
60FPS locked.
No Borderless Windowed mode.
No non-standard resolutions.
And no FOV or camera settings.
But it DOES have HDR.

I'm pretty tolerant when it comes to this stuff, I don't really care about graphics or FPS or anything.
But the V-sync input lag is huge and there's no kind of adaptive sync or nvidia reflex here to help offset it. If you are on a high end PC, you WILL need to unlock the FPS to get it playable.
It also does the Elden Ring thing of cutting off the sides of the screen if you have a non-standard aspect ratio. But it doesn't change the FOV of the camera. So when I got to the 1st boss, I couldn't even see the top half of his body to parry his attacks.

That's when I spent about 3 hours trying to mod the game to get 144FPS, borderless windowed, ultrawide support (black bar removal, UI fix and vertical FOV fix) and I just couldn't get all of them to work at the same time.
I just settled for 144FPS, FOV and resolution.
The game runs and plays great now.

But after beating Lies of P which just has all that stuff natively, spending so much time messing around with .dlls and .exes and patchers when all I wanted to do was play the game was frustrating and a huge let down.

I really hope From Software steps up their game and starts making actual PC ports one day.

Game title: Serkiro: Shadows Die Twice
Overall Rating: âââââ

1. Gameplay
	â¢	Precise, smooth and, rewarding
	â¢	Challenging gameplay that rewards the player for being attentive to the enemy
	â¢	FromSoft decided to give the player no choice in character building, and very limited options in character leveling which some might not enjoy if they are fans of the previous entires. Although I found this off-putting at first I canât deny that it just makes sense. You can't just over level your way through this entry you got to learn and improve, if you want to get through this game. 

2. Graphics & Art Style
	â¢	The gameâs visuals beautifully capture the atmosphere of Sengoku-era Japan, with lush environments and striking character designs.
	â¢	Graphics hold up very well, although I could have appreciated if the game wasn't locked in at 60fpsâ¨

3. Sound & Music
	â¢	You will be addicted to listening to the sound the deflect makes when you hit it perfectly
	â¢	The soundtrack enhances the experience when entering a boss fight or just navigating through areas

4. Story & Writing
	â¢	First play through I didn't get much of the story as it took the backseat while I focused on not dying around every corner
	â¢	Second play through I got to pay a bit more attention and really enjoy the story that at times can feel hidden but still interesting. 
        â¢	I love that there are several endings kept me coming back

5. Performance & Stability
	â¢	Minimal to no bugs, with stable 60fps throughout my entire playtime

6. Replayability & Content
        â¢	As mentioned before there are several endings which kept me coming back but recently the devs have added new modes. You can now replay boss fights as I recall if you beat the challenging gauntlet modes you unlock cosmetics

7. Value for Money
	â¢	The game to me is worth the $60 but frequently goes on sale making it super worth the money
	â¢	NO MICROTRANSACTIONS

Positives
	â¢	Great challenge, great atmosphere
Negatives
	â¢	locked in at 60fps
	â¢	Not personally a negative for me but it might be for some, there is no multiplayer, and it's so challenging that it can feel frustrating at times. (get gud)

Would you recommend this game?
	â¢	Yes

Sekiro is one of those games that gets better every time you replay it. Unlike many games, it offers a more simple and cohesive vision. It doesn't try to do everything at once - instead, it focuses on its core combat and movement mechanics, then gives you the space to learn them. That's what makes Sekiro's combat so satisfying, your success doesn't come from stat upgrades, but from your actual growth as a player.
